spots.name: Hidden Garden Steps
spots.body: The Hidden Garden Steps has 148 steps. It is a volunteer driven, community based public art.

spots.name: The Painted Ladies
spots.body: Painted Ladies is a name applied to San Francisco's restored Victorian era homes that are painted three or more colors. These houses tend to feature two or more trim colors and one base color. One of the most famous blocks of Painted Ladies exists on Postcard Row.

spots.name: Palace Of Fine Arts
spots.body: The Palace of Fine Arts was built for the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition and remains the only structure left from the fair. Greek and Roman architecture themes influenced Palace designer, Bernard Maybeck. In 1965, the Palace was stripped to its bare metal and rebuilt for future generation to enjoy. The Palace is inside a park of the same name with a large lagoon. Adjoining the palace is a theater, and a fun for all ages science museum.

spots.name: Twin Peaks
spots.body: The Twin Peaks are two hills with an elevation of about 904 feet and 910 feet. They are the second highest hills, next to Mount Davidson. During the daytime on a clear day, all landmarks of the northern part of San Francisco are seen. When the Spanish Conquistadors and settlers arrived at the beginning of the 18th century, they called the area Breasts of the Indian Maiden and devoted the area to ranching. When San Francisco passed under American control during the 19th century, it was renamed Twin Peaks.

spots.name: Coit Tower
spots.body: Coit Tower is a 210 foot tower in the Telegraph Hill. The tower was built in 1933 using Lillie Hitchcock Coit's bequest to beautify the city of San Francisco. She was a well known patroness of San Francisco's volunteer firefighters. Before December 1866, there was no city fire department. There are some pretty cool 1930s era murals inside the base of the tower. The structure is probably one of the best examples of Art Deco architecture in San Francisco.

spots.name: City Hall
spots.body: City Hall is the centerpiece of the San Francisco government, and home to the offices of the Mayor as well as the city Supervisors. It has been nicknamed Willie's Dome due to its extensive gold refurbishment by Mayor Willie Brown. It was also the site of the infamous shootings of George Moscone and Harvey Milk. The original City Hall was completed in 1899 after 27 years of planning and construction. It was destroyed during San Francisco earthquake. Reopened in 1915, it is a Beaux Arts monument to the City Beautiful movement that epitomized the high minded American Renaissance of the 1880s to 1917.

spots.name: Lombard Street
spots.body: Lombard Street is famous for having a steep, one block section where the road has eight sharp turns. The Powell Hyde cable car line stops at the top of the block. The design was created in 1922 due to the hill's natural 27% grade, which was too steep for most vehicles to travel.

spots.name: Fort Point
spots.body: Fort Point is designed to hold 126 cannons. In 1769, Spain occupied the San Francisco area, and they had established the area's first European settlement by 1776. To protect against encroachment by the British and Russians, Spain fortified the high white cliff at the narrowest part of the bay's entrance, where Fort Point now stands. Mexico won independence from Spain in 1821, gaining control of the region and the fort, but in 1835 the Mexican army moved to Sonoma leaving the castillo's adobe walls to crumble in the wind and rain. On July 1, 1846, after the Mexican American War broke out between Mexico and the United States, following the United States' victory in 1848, California was annexed by the U.S. and became a state in 1850. The Fort was built by the U.S. Army between 1853 and 1861. It was also a location for Union soldiers during the Civil War.

spots.name: Grateful Dead House
spots.body: The Grateful Dead, which was an American rock band formed in 1965, lived there from 1966 until 1968. The band and its fans, Deadheads, are closely associated with the hippie movement and were seen as an American cultural institution for many years.

spots.name: The 16th Avenue Tiled Steps
spots.body: The 16th Avenue Tiled Steps has 163 steps in a Sea to Sky theme. Following the next steps up will lead to Grand View Park. This project started in 2003.

spots.name: Chinatown Gate
spots.body: Within Chinatown there are two major thoroughfares. One is the Chinatown Gate at the intersection of Bush Street and Grant Avenue. Built in 1970, this gate is the southern entrance to Chinatown. It is inscribed with the saying All under heaven is for the good of the people.

spots.name: Mission Dolores
spots.body: Mission Dolores was founded on June 29, 1776. It is the oldest intact building in all of San Francisco and the only mission chapel still intact to be built. Its original location was near the village of Chutchui, which was at the current corner of Camp and Albion streets. It was moved to its current location in 1791.

spots.name: Wave Organ
spots.body: The Wave Organ is a wave activated acoustic sculpture built in 1986 by Peter Richards and George Gonzales in collaboration with the San Francisco Exploratorium. The Wave Organ is located at the end of a jetty in the Golden Gate Yacht Club. The jetty itself was constructed with debris from the demolished Laurel Hill Cemetery and these marble fragments were worked into the Wave Organ's construction.

spots.name: Flood Building
spots.body: Completed in 1904, the Flood Building has withstood San Francisco earthquake and the threat of demolition. It houses over 350 diverse tenants including the flagship store for Gap, as well as stores for Urban Outfitters, Anthropologie and T Mobile. The Baldwin Hotel & Theater occupied the site of today's Flood Building. It was destroyed by fire in 1898. In 1902, James L. Flood purchased the plot of land that held the remains of the Baldwin Hotel and hired architect Albert Pissis to build a building in honor of his late father James Clair Flood, who passed away in 1889.

spots.name: Haas-Lilienthal House
spots.body: The Haas Lilienthal House is the city's only intact Victorian era home that is open regularly as a museum, complete with authentic furniture and artifacts. William Haas entrusted Bavarian architect Peter R. Schmidt to build his home in 1886.

spots.name: Transamerica Pyramid
spots.body: Transamerica Pyramid is the tallest and most recognizable building in the skyline of San Francisco. It has a structural height of 853 feet and contains 48 floors of retail and office space. Construction began in 1969 and finished in 1972. In 1972, it was the eighth tallest building in the world.

spots.name: The Golden Gate Bridge
spots.body: The Golden Gate Bridge is a suspension bridge spanning the Golden Gate strait, the one mile wide, one point seven mile long channel between San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean. It is one of the most famous suspension bridges in the world. The bridge was designed by Joseph Strauss, and built in 1936. It is well known for its distinctive color and architecture and, along with cable cars, is perhaps the most iconic feature of San Francisco. The bridge is painted a color called International Orange, designed for high visibility in contrast with surroundings and yet harmonizing well with the natural landscape.

spots.name: Cupid's Span
spots.body: Cupid's Span is an outdoor sculpture by married artists Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen. The 60 foot sculpture, commissioned by GAP founders Donald and Doris F. Fisher in 2002, depicts a partial bow and piece of an arrow.

spots.name: Lotta's Fountain
spots.body: Lotta's Fountain was commissioned by Lotta Crabtree as a gift to the city of San Francisco. It was dedicated on September 9, 1875. During the fountain's centennial anniversary, it was added to the list of both the San Francisco Designated Landmarks and the U.S National Register of Historic Places.

spots.name: Sutro Tower
spots.body: Sutro Tower is a 977 feet three pronged TV and radio antenna tower in San Francisco. Before the construction of Sutro Tower in 1973, television reception in San Francisco was spotty because the many hills of the city blocked the line of sight television signal.

spots.name: Stow Lake
spots.body: Stow Lake is a manmade lake in Golden Gate Park with a rich history that dates back to 1893. There is a bright red pagoda which is a gift given to the park from San Francisco's sister city of Taipei. The Boathouse is open 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. every day of the week. It is ready to provide you with a vessel of your choosing.

spots.name: Golden Gate Park Windmills
spots.body: There are two functioning windmills on the western edge of Golden Gate Park. The northern Dutch Windmill was completed in 1903, and the southern Murphy Windmill was completed in 1908. In the 1870s and 1880s, Golden Gate Park was planted on sand dunes and required substantial irrigation. In 1902, the Park Commission authorized the construction of two windmills to pump groundwater for park irrigation rather than purchasing water at exorbitant costs from the Spring Valley Water Company.

spots.name: Alfred E. Clarke Mansion
spots.body: The Clarke Mansion survived the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and subsequent fires which had destroyed many of the Victorian mansions from the same era. The mansion was used briefly as a hospital. Today, it is used as a rental property, with 15 apartments. It was built in 1891. Originally, an Irish policeman with a very colorful reputation owned the mansion.

spots.name: Columbus Tower
spots.body: Columbus Tower, also known as the Sentinel Building is a distinctive copper green Flatiron Building, completed in 1907. Despite the 1907 finish, building work had begun before the San Francisco earthquake the previous year, but extensive damage to the building site, and the rest of the city, slowed down the construction considerably. Around 1949, the nightclub hungry i, which would become very influential in the history of stand up comedy in the US, was opened as a 83 seat venue in the Sentinel Building's basement by Eric Nord, who sold it to Enrico Banducci in 1951.

spots.name: Fort Miley
spots.body: The Fort Miley Military Reservation was acquired by the U.S. Army in 1893 and used as part of the seacoast defense of San Francisco Harbor during the early phases of America's involvement in World War 2.

spots.name: Gandhi Statue
spots.body: Mohandas K. Gandhi is a 1988 bronze sculpture of Mahatma Gandhi. The 8 foot tall sculpture was a gift from the Gandhi Memorial International Foundation.

spots.name: Bay Bridge
spots.body: San Francisco Oakland Bay Bridge is a complex of bridges spanning San Francisco Bay. It carries about 240000 vehicles a day on its two decks. It has one of the longest spans in the United States. The toll bridge was conceived as early as the Gold Rush days, but construction did not begin until 1933. Bay Bridge was designed by Charles H. Purcell, and built by American Bridge Company. It opened on November 12, 1936, six months before the Golden Gate Bridge.

spots.name: Chinese Historical Society of America
spots.body: The Chinese Historical Society of America is the oldest and largest organization in the country dedicated to the documentation, study, and presentation of Chinese American history.

spots.name: Mount Olympus
spots.body: Mount Olympus was once considered to mark the geographical center of the city, and was topped off by a statue given by Adolph Sutro, the Triumph of Light, now lost. Only the statue's pedestal remains, and the view from the top is obstructed by trees and condominiums.

spots.name: Pier 39
spots.body: Pier 39 is a shopping center and one of the most popular tourist attraction built on a pier. There are more than 10 restaurants, 90+ shops, a video arcade, street performances, the Aquarium of the Bay, and California sea lions that haul out on docks on Pier 39's marina. A two story carousel is one of the pier's more dominant features.

spots.name: Muir Woods National Monument
spots.body: Muir Woods National Monument is an old growth coastal redwood forest, which is 12 miles north of San Francisco. The main attraction of Muir Woods are the coast redwood trees. They are known for their height. While redwoods can grow to nearly 380 feet, the tallest tree in the Muir Woods is 258 feet. Most of the redwoods in the monument are between 500 and 800 years old. The oldest is at least 1200 years old.

spots.name: Holocaust Memorial
spots.body: Holocaust Memorial was created by artist George Segal out of white painted bronze. Several of the bodies in the sculpture were designed to be symbolic. One of the bodies resembles Christ, another is of a woman holding an apple. Both symbolize the connection between Jews and Christians. The only standing man is thought to be the sculptor's representation of Margaret Bourke White's famous Life magazine 1945 photograph of the liberation of Buchenwald. She was an American photographer and documentary photographer.

spots.name: Torpedo Wharf
spots.body: There has been a wharf at this site since 1854. Over the years, it has been rebuilt several times and finally became Torpedo Wharf when the Army constructed a submarine mine depot here around 1907 to 1909. The Army used the wharf to plant underwater mines as part of the harbor defense.

spots.name: Spreckels Mansion
spots.body: Spreckels Mansion is French Baroque chateau which was designed for Adolph and Alma de Bretteville Spreckels by George A. Applegarth, a graduate of the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris. To accommodate his grand chateau, Spreckels bought and combined several prime lots with views of the San Francisco Bay and the Golden Gate. Adolph Spreckels was the son of sugar tycoon Claus Spreckels. He inherited and expanded his father's empire, to include sugar cane in Hawaii and sugar beets in the Salinas Valley along with the necessary refineries. Alma, the daughter of poor Danish immigrants, was born in the Sunset District. Her beauty and taste for fine art led her to model for local artists. Alma continued her interest in the fine arts. She purchased a number of major works by Auguste Rodin and commissioned Applegarth to design the California Palace of the Legion of Honor.

spots.name: The Peace Pagoda
spots.body: The Peace Pagoda is a five tiered concrete stupa in San Francisco's Japantown. The pagoda was constructed in the 1960s and presented to San Francisco by its sister city Osaka, Japan on March 28, 1968. It was designed by Japanese architect Yoshiro Taniguchi.

spots.name: Battery Mendell
spots.body: Battery Mendell was the first of the batteries built at Fort Barry. Construction was started in July 1901 and was completed in 1902. On 22 November 1902, War Department General Order 120 named the battery after Colonel George H. Mendell, Corps of Engineers. In 1905, two M1895A4 12 inch breech loading rifles arrived on this site. They were mounted on disappearing carriages. These guns fired a 1100 pound projectile over eight miles. These guns remained emplaced until 1943, when the threat of imminent invasion was over. The guns were removed and scrapped that same year.

spots.name: Nightingale House
spots.body: The Nightingale House is a Victorian era Queen Anne and Eastlake style house. It was designed by architect John Marquis and built in 1882. Notably the last resident of this house was San Francisco Arts Commissioner and San Francisco artist Jo Hanson, who died March 13, 2007.

spots.name: The Music Concourse
spots.body: The Music Concourse is a vital civic and cultural space within Golden Gate Park, hosting free concerts on Sundays during the summer and serving as a respite and picnic spot year round for visitors to nearby cultural facilities.

spots.name: Battery Townsley
spots.body: Battery Townsley was a casemated battery that mounted two 16 inch caliber guns, each capable of shooting a 2100 pound projectile 25 miles out to sea. Completed in 1940, the guns and their associated ammunition magazines, power rooms, and crew quarters protected from air and naval attack.

spots.name: Invocation Statue
spots.body: Invocation Statue was installed in 2004, to mark the beginning of a new bike path. The sculptor, Pepe Ozan, stated that the piece represents an Eagle Warrior, an institution that survived all of Mesoamerica's civilizations throughout 2000 years until the arrival of the Conquistadors. The Eagle Warriors were a corps of elite who served as leaders in religious ceremonies as well as on the battlefield.

spots.name: Le Petit Trianon
spots.body: San Francisco has several representations of European landmarks, including Marie Antoinette's Le Petit Trianon. The original building at Versailles Palace in France was built between 1763 and 1768 for Louis 15 favorite mistress, Madame de Pompadour. This copy was built from 1902 to 1904 for Marcus Koshland and Corinne Koshland.

spots.name: Diego Rivera Mural Project
spots.body: The Diego Rivera Mural Project, sponsored by City College of San Francisco, has as its mission the return of the mural to the position of public importance and influence envisioned by its creator. The organizers of the 1940 Golden Gate International Exposition commissioned Diego Rivera to paint a large scale fresco during the run of the fair.

spots.name: Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center
spots.body: Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center, dedicated to telling the bridge's story, is the place where visitors can see authentic relics like hard hats and rivets from the Golden Gate Bridge's construction in the 1930s, watch a short orientation video, and check out the 12 foot test tower that was used in 1933 to evaluate the bridge's design.

spots.name: Point Bonita Lighthouse
spots.body: Point Bonita Lighthouse is a lighthouse located at the San Francisco Bay entrance near Sausalito. It was the last manned lighthouse on the California coast. The original Point Bonita Lighthouse, a 56 foot brick tower, was 306 feet above sea level. Unfortunately, the Fresnel lens was often cloaked in fog and could not be seen from the sea. The West Coast has dense high fog, which leaves lower elevations clear. In 1877, the lighthouse was moved to its current location at 124 feet above sea level.

spots.name: Camera Obscura
spots.body: The Camera Obscura was built in 1946, and is a large scale dark room to take a traditional pinhole image in the Lands End area. The Camera is currently owned by the National Park Service.

spots.name: Alcatraz Island
spots.body: Alcatraz Island is located in the San Francisco Bay, 1.25 miles offshore from San Francisco. The ferry service is offered from Pier 33, near Fisherman's Wharf. The small island offers a close up look at the site of the first lighthouse and US built fort on the West Coast, the infamous federal penitentiary long off limits to the public, and the history making 18 month occupation by Indians of All Tribes. Rich in history, there is also a natural side to the Rock gardens, tide pools, bird colonies, and bay views beyond compare.

spots.name: San Francisco Veterans Memorial
spots.body: San Francisco Veterans Memorial is one of the largest performing arts centers in the United States. It covers 7.5 acres in the Civic Center Historic District. The complex was developed in the 1920s on two blocks. The War Memorial name commemorates all the people who served in the First World War. It was designed by Arthur Brown Jr. in 1927 to 1928, and is one of the last Beaux Arts style structures erected in the United States. The War Memorial Opera House and the multi purpose Veterans Building next door were completed and opened in 1932.

spots.name: USS San Francisco Memorial
spots.body: USS San Francisco, a New Orleans class cruiser, was the second ship of three of the United States Navy named after the city of San Francisco. Commissioned in 1934, during the December 1942 repair at Mare Island, it was necessary to extensively rebuild the bridge. The bridge wings were removed as part of that repair, and are now part of a memorial to the ship on a promontory in Lands End.

spots.name: Kanrin Maru Monument
spots.body: Kanrin Maru Monument is erected to commemorate the arrival of the first Japanese Naval Ship Kanrin Maru in San Francisco on 17 March, 1860. The Kanrin Maru crossed the Pacific at the same time as the U.S.S. Powhatan which brought the first Japanese Embassy to the United States.

spots.name: Lands End Labyrinth
spots.body: Lands End Labyrinth was created by Eduardo Aguilera in 2004. Eduardo grew up in Mexico and came to the US in 1966. Living in southern California until 1983 he moved to San Francisco, operating his own auto detailing business.

spots.name: Engine Company 33
spots.body: Victorian style Engine Company 33 was built on property purchased in 1895 from Delia Hall and Albert Hall. Designed by Charles R. Wilson and constructed entirely of redwood, the firehouse has 20 foot ceilings on two floors. The building facade incorporates classical revival architectural influences with symmetrical and geometric embellishments.

spots.name: US Customs House
spots.body: The US custom house is a historic custom house which was built to house offices of the United States Customs Service. San Francisco rapidly expanded during the nineteenth century. Due to construction of the Panama Canal, city officials likely anticipated increased commerce and determined that a larger custom house was needed. In 1905, Eames and Young, a St. Louis architectural firm, won a national design competition for a new custom house. They designed the building in the Beaux Arts Classicism style.

spots.name: Jones Street Tank
spots.body: Jones Street Tank is part of the city's larger Auxiliary Water Supply System. After 1906 San Francisco earthquake, the fire destroyed huge swaths of San Francisco, voters passed a bond issue in 1909 that created the San Francisco Fire Department Auxiliary Water Supply System.

spots.name: Abraham Lincoln Brigade Memorial
spots.body: In 1936, General Francisco Franco led a military uprising to overthrow the elected government of Spain. Forty thousand people went to Spain to fight for democracy. The 2700 Americans who joined the fight were known as the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. On Sunday, March 30, 2008, the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade unveiled Abraham Lincoln Brigade Memorial as a monument. It was designed by Ann Chamberlain and Walter Hood. Visual artist Ann Chamberlain taught at several Bay Area colleges.

spots.name: United Nations Plaza
spots.body: United Nations Plaza, located adjacent to Market Street, is the gateway to City Hall. The plaza is surrounded by both the Asian Art Museum and the SF Main Public Library, and contains several historic statues and a fountain. A weekly farmers market, called the Heart of the City Farmers Market, is a diverse and popular attraction for locals.

spots.name: Vaillancourt Fountain
spots.body: Vaillancourt Fountain was designed by the Quebecois artist Armand Vaillancourt in 1971. It is about 40 feet high and is constructed out of precast concrete square tubes.

spots.name: Tony Bennett Statue
spots.body: Tony Bennett sang 'I Left My Heart in San Francisco' in 1961 outside the city's Fairmont Hotel, and it was there a statue of the singer was just erected for his 90th birthday.

spots.name: Korean War Memorial
spots.body: During the Korean War, more than 50000 Americans and one million Koreans lost their lives. In honor of those who served and sacrificed during this war, Korean War Memorial opened at the Presidio on August 1, 2016.

spots.name: Central Tower
spots.body: Central Tower is a 299 feet 21 story office building. The building has undergone numerous renovations since its completion in 1898. In 1890, built as San Francisco's first skyscraper. The building eventually stood 315 feet tall with an ornate Baroque dome, and the construction finished in 1898. The structure was badly burned and damaged by the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. In 1938 Albert Roller completely refurbished Central Tower. The building's height was reduced to 298 feet and the number of stories was increased from 15 to 21. The ornate dome was removed.

spots.name: Statue of Miguel Hidalgo
spots.body: Statue of Miguel Hidalgo by Juan Fernando Olaguibel was cast in bronze in Mexico and presented to the City of San Francisco by the Mexican Community September 16, 1963. The liberation of Mexico after 300 years of domination by Spain started on September 16, 1810, in the town of Dolores in what is now the state of Guanajuato, Mexico. A priest, Miguel Hidalgo, and other patriots, among whom were Juan Aldama and Ignacio Allende, were at first successful but eventually Miguel Hidalgo was captured and executed. The war continued until its final victory in 1821 under the leadership of Vicente Guerrero and Agustin de Itrubide.

spots.name: Bank of America Building
spots.body: Bank of America Building is a 52 story 778 feet skyscraper. It is the second tallest building in the city, the largest by floor area, and a focal point of the Financial District. Completed in 1969, the tower was the tallest building on the West Coast until the completion of the Transamerica Pyramid in 1972. The skyscraper has thousands of bay windows thanks to its unique design, meant to improve the rental value and to symbolize the bay windows common in San Francisco residential real estate. The irregular cutout areas near the top of the building were designed to suggest the Sierra mountains.

spots.name: The Marine Mammal Center
spots.body: The Marine Mammal Center is a private, non profit organization that was established for the purpose of rescuing, rehabilitating, and releasing, marine mammals who are injured, ill, or abandoned. It also serves as a center for environmental research and education regarding marine mammals, namely cetaceans and pinnipeds.

spots.name: Battery Kirby
spots.body: Battery Kirby is a reinforced concrete gun battery. Battery construction was begun in 1899, completed in 1900. It was transferred to the Coast Artillery for use 1900, and deactivated in 1941.

spots.name: La Chiffonniere
spots.body: Created by the French artist Jean Dubuffet in 1978, La Chiffonniere shows a woman wearing abstracted rags. Dubuffet considered art made by children and the mentally ill to be the purest form of expression, and he pioneered this Art Brut movement in the 1940s.

spots.name: Broderick Terry Duel Site
spots.body: Broderick Terry duel was fought between United States Senator David C. Broderick, of California, and ex Chief Justice David S. Terry, of the Supreme Court of California, on September 13, 1859. The two men had been friends and political allies within the Democratic Party. However, Broderick was an abolitionist, whereas Terry was pro slavery.

spots.name: Moore Road Pier
spots.body: Moore Road Pier offers not only decent fishing but one of the worlds most beautiful views such as the Golden Gate Bridge, Angel Island, Alcatraz Island, and an unending number of boats. It was a former military wharf.

spots.name: Hard Bop
spots.body: Hard Bop is a sculpture designed by John Atkin in October 2008. Hard Bop is also a subgenre of jazz that is an extension of bebop music.

spots.name: Nike Missile Control Site SF-87
spots.body: Nike Missile Control Site SF 87 was activated in 1955, deactivated in 1971. The IFC has one steel radar platform, and a few concrete pads.

spots.name: World War 2 Memorial
spots.body: Dedicated November 29, 1960, the West Coast World War 2 Memorial is a curved wall of California granite set in a grove of Monterey pine and cypress. Overlooking the Pacific Ocean, it bears the names of 413 members of the armed forces who were lost or buried at sea in U.S. Pacific waters between 1941 and 1945.

spots.name: Fort Gunny Bags
spots.body: In 1856 Fort Gunny Bags was a warehouse surrounded by gunny bags that served as the headquarters for the city's 2500 man self appointed, Second Vigilance Committee. Fed up with crime and lawlessness the vigilante group arrested, tried, and hanged men on this spot in order to stop the crime. After a number of public hangings, the crime did indeed stop.

spots.name: Duboce Bikeway Mural
spots.body: Duboce Bikeway Mural by Mona Caron is a 6000 square foot mural celebrates the first street in San Francisco to become a dedicated bikeway. The mural shows bicyclists crossing the city from the bay to the ocean on the famed bike route The Wiggle.

spots.name: Nike Missile Site SF-88
spots.body: During the tense years of the Cold War, from 1953 to 1979, the United States Army built and operated close to 300 Nike missile sites in the United States. These sites were designed as the last line of defense against Soviet bombers. Today, a dedicated group of volunteers works in partnership with the Golden Gate National Recreation Area on the continuous task of restoration at site SF 88L, the only fully restored Nike missile site in the country.

spots.name: Liberty Bell Slot Machine Historical Site
spots.body: The Liberty Bell was the first variation of the modern mechanical slot machine we see today, originally being referred to as a fruit machine or one armed bandit. Created in 1895 by Charles Fey, a car mechanic from San Francisco, the Liberty Bell's popularity set the standard for the modern slot machine; its three reel model is still used today despite great advances in slot technology over the past several decades. The original Liberty Bell slot machine is currently on display at the Liberty Belle saloon in Reno, Nevada as a historic artifact.

spots.name: Prayer Book Cross
spots.body: Prayer Book Cross situated on one of the highest points in the park was a tribute to the first English language sermon and use of the Book of Common Prayer in California. The cross is one of the tallest in the city, measuring nearly 60 feet tall. Erected in 1894, millions of people have come to see this gift from the Church of England.

spots.name: Old Saint Hilary's Church
spots.body: Old Saint Hilary's Church was built in 1888. It is one of the few California examples of Carpenter's Gothic style to survive in its original condition and setting. It's situated atop a knoll. The small white clapboard building with high peaked roof has interior walls of natural redwood, a ceiling of Douglas fir, oak pews and is lit by replicas of the original oil burning chandeliers. The only original stained glass window, which is above the door, depicts Saint Hilary who is patron saint of scholars. The other windows are Gothic arches of amber glass.

spots.name: Battery Crosby
spots.body: Battery Crosby was named in honor of Lieutenant Franklin B. Crosby, Fourth Artillery, who was killed in the Civil War battle at Chancellorsville, Virginia in May 1863. It was built to protect underwater minefields laid outside the Golden Gate, this Endicott era battery was completed and armed in 1900. Armed with two 6 inch guns mounted on disappearing carriages, Battery Crosby's artillery had a range of eight miles and could fire at the rate of two rounds per minute. During World War 2, these guns were assigned to the Mine Groupment designed to concentrate fire on the harbor entrance and minefields. Throughout this period, Battery Crosby was manned by the Sixth Coast Artillery Regiment. In 1943, the War Department officially closed the battery and its guns were scrapped.

spots.name: Roald Amundsen Marker
spots.body: Roald Amundsen, the Norwegian polar explorer, was the first to detect the magnetic North Pole. The San Francisco Norwegian community purchased the his ship from Amundsen and donated it to the people of San Francisco in 1909. In 1911, Amundsen became the first explorer to reach the South Pole. The ship remained at this site at the western end of Golden Gate Park until 1972, when it was returned to Norway. The restored ship is now on display at the Maritime Museum in Oslo. The Amundsen Monument is a stone shaft of Norwegian granite which was donated by Bay Area Norwegians March 1, 1930.

spots.name: Liberty Street Historic District
spots.body: Liberty Street Historic District is an intact example of 19th century middle class housing and developmental practices. It is one of the earliest residential suburbs to be developed in San Francisco, with major development starting in the 1860s and continuing until the turn of the century. Because the fire following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake was stopped at the 20th Street boundary of the district, it contains examples of all architectural styles prevalent during the developmental period.

spots.name: Immigration Station
spots.body: From 1910 to 1940, Angel Island was an immigration station where immigrants entering the United States were detained and interrogated. Angel Island Immigration Station served as a fishing and hunting site for Coastal Miwok Indians, then it was a haven for Spanish explorer Juan Manuel de Ayala, later it was constructed as a cattle ranch, and then served as a U.S. Army post starting with the Civil War. Most importantly, it was the island that held hundreds of thousands of immigrants, the majority from China and Japan. The detention facility was considered ideal because of its isolated location, making it very easy to control migrants, as well as any outbreaks of disease, and enforce the new immigration laws.

spots.name: Rialto Building
spots.body: Rialto Building is an eight story H shaped court. It has a steel frame clad in brick and terra cotta. The eighth story is highly ornamented. The facade accommodated the lack of interior partition walls by providing a large space between the window mullions. Originally constructed in 1902, it was reconstructed in 1910 after the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and Fire.

spots.name: Cadillac Hotel
spots.body: Cadillac Hotel was designed by the architectural firm of Meyer and O'Brien in the Renaissance/Baroque style with Art Nouveau influences and a three part design unusual in apartment hotel construction. Its construction in 1908 foreshadowed the development of the Tenderloin as a major residential neighborhood stimulated by the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition. For many years beginning in 1924, Cadillac Hotel was the home of Newman's Gym, reputed to be the oldest professional boxing facility in the United States.

spots.name: Mile Rocks Lighthouse
spots.body: Mile Rocks Lighthouse is a lighthouse on a rock about 2 miles southwest of the Golden Gate Bridge. It's now an automated and unnatural looking lighthouse with a flat top and barberpole like painted rings. In 1889, the United States Lighthouse Service placed a bell buoy near the rocks. However, the strong currents in the area would pull the buoy beneath the surface of the water and set it adrift. The lighthouse was completed in 1906 after considerable difficulty caused by the heavy seas and strong currents occurring at this point. The original third order Fresnel lens was transferred to the Old Point Loma lighthouse in SanDiego. In 1966, all of the tower was removed and only the first story was left, and the light automated. The top of the first story is now a landing pad.

spots.name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
spots.body: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art is a modern art museum. The museum's current collection includes over 33000 works of painting, sculpture, photography, architecture, design, and media arts. It is one of the largest in the United States overall, and one of the largest in the world for modern and contemporary art.

spots.name: De Young Museum
spots.body: De Young Museum is one of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco along with the Legion of Honor. The museum opened in 1895 as an outgrowth of the California Midwinter International Exposition of 1894. It was housed in an Egyptian revival structure which had been the Fine Arts Building at the fair. The building was badly damaged in the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, closing the building for a year and a half for repairs. The coordinator for architecture for the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition designed the Spanish Plateresque style building.

spots.name: Asian Art Museum
spots.body: The Asian Art Museum of San Francisco houses one of the most comprehensive Asian art collections in the world, with more than 18000 works of art in its permanent collection, some as much as 6000 years old. The museum owes its origin to a donation to the city of San Francisco by Chicago millionaire Avery Brundage, who was a major collector of Asian art.

spots.name: Legion of Honor
spots.body: The Legion of Honor displays a collection spanning more than 6000 years of ancient and European art and houses the Achenbach Foundation for Graphic Arts in a neoclassical building overlooking Lincoln Park and the Golden Gate Bridge. The Legion of Honor was the gift of Alma de Bretteville Spreckels, wife of the sugar magnate and thoroughbred racehorse owner Adolph B. Spreckels. The building is a full scale replica, by George Applegarth, of the French Pavilion at the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition, which in turn was a three quarter scale version of the HÃ´tel de Salm in Paris, by Pierre Rousseau.

spots.name: The Walt Disney Family Museum
spots.body: The Walt Disney Family Museum is an American museum that features the life and legacy of Walt Disney. The 40000 square foot space in the main museum building features the newest technology and historic materials and artifacts to bring Disney's achievements to life, with interactive galleries that include early drawings and animation, movies, music, listening stations, and a 12 foot diameter model of Disneyland.

spots.name: Contemporary Jewish Museum
spots.body: The Contemporary Jewish Museum was founded in 1984 and was housed in a small gallery space near San Francisco's waterfront. The museum created a more expansive and centrally located facility with increased exhibitions, an area dedicated to education, and added program areas including live music, theater, dance, literary events, and film.

spots.name: California Academy of Sciences
spots.body: The California Academy of Sciences is a natural history museum that is among the largest museums of natural history in the world. The Academy began in 1853 as a learned society and still carries out a large amount of original research, with exhibits and education becoming significant endeavors of the museum during the 20th century, including anthropology, marine biology, botany, entomology, herpetology, ichthyology, invertebrate zoology, mammalogy, ornithology, geology, and paleontology.

spots.name: Exploratorium
spots.body: The Exploratorium is a public learning laboratory exploring the world through science, art, and human perception. It opened in 1969 at the Palace of Fine Arts, and reopened at Piers 15 and 17 in 2013. The historic interior and exterior of Pier 15 was renovated extensively prior to the move, and is divided into several galleries mainly separated by content, including the physics of Light and Sound, Human Behavior, Living Systems, the Outdoor Gallery, and the Bay Observatory Gallery, which focuses on local environment, weather, and landscape.

spots.name: Museum of the African Diaspora
spots.body: The Museum of the African Diaspora is a museum documenting the African Diaspora. The Museum showcases the history, art, and cultural richness that resulted from the migration of Africans throughout the world.

spots.name: San Francisco Cable Car Museum
spots.body: The Cable Car Museum is a free museum. The museum contains several examples of old cable cars, together with smaller exhibits and a shop. It is part of the complex that also houses the cable car power house, which drives the cables, and the car depot.

spots.name: Cartoon Art Museum
spots.body: The Cartoon Art Museum is the only museum in the Western United States dedicated to the preservation and exhibition of all forms of cartoon art. The permanent collection features some 7000 pieces as of 2015, including original animation cels, comic book pages and sculptures.

spots.name: MusÃ©e MÃ©canique
spots.body: The MusÃ©e MÃ©canique is a for profit interactive museum consisting of 20th century penny arcade games and artifacts. The museum owns over 300 mechanical machines, and is one of the largest privately owned collection of such games in the world. Owner Ed Zelinsky began collecting at age 11 and his games were exhibited in the 1920s at Playland. The museum was featured in the 2001 film The Princess Diaries and in a 2011 episode of the Japanese television show GameCenter CX.

spots.name: Randall Museum
spots.body: Randall Museum focuses on science, nature and the arts. On exhibit are live native and domestic animals and interactive displays about nature. Other facilities include a theater, a wood shop, and art and ceramics studios.

spots.name: San Francisco Railway Museum
spots.body: San Francisco Railway Museum features exhibits on the antique streetcars of the Market and Fisherman's Wharves and national landmark cable cars that continue to run along the city's major arteries. The admission to the museum is free.

spots.name: Mexican Museum
spots.body: Founded in 1975 by San Francisco artist Peter RodrÃ­guez, Mexican Museum holds a permanent collection of over 14000 objects including Pre Hispanic, Colonial, Popular, Mexican and Latino Modern, and Mexican, Latino, and Chicano Contemporary art.

spots.name: Museo ItaloAmericano
spots.body: Museo ItaloAmericano is the only museum focusing solely on Italian and Italian American art and culture in California. The nonprofit museum was founded in 1978. Although the museum always holds temporary exhibits, it also maintains a permanent collection, including works by Beniamino Bufano, Francesco Clemente, Sandro Chia, Mimmo Paladino, among others.

spots.name: Museum of Performance & Design
spots.body: Museum of Performance & Design collects and makes accessible materials about the performing arts, with a special emphasis on documenting and preserving the San Francisco Bay Area's rich and diverse performing arts heritage from the Gold Rush to the present. The museum's collection includes personal papers of prominent artists, original costumes and design renderings, audio visual recordings of live performances, original artwork, other artifacts and ephemera.

spots.name: San Francisco Fire Department Museum
spots.body: San Francisco Fire Department Museum is small, free museum exhibiting antique fire engines, helmets, extinguishers & other San Francisco Fire Department memorabilia.

spots.name: Wattis Institute for Contemporary Arts
spots.body: The Wattis Institute for Contemporary Arts is a contemporary art center and part of the California College of the Arts. It was established in 1998 to serve as a forum for the presentation and discussion of international contemporary art and curatorial practise and a premiere venue for contemporary art exhibitions worldwide.

spots.name: Madame Tussauds San Francisco
spots.body: Madame Tussauds San Francisco is a wax museum located in Fisherman's Wharf. The attraction features wax figures of famous figures from movies, music, politics, popular culture and sport.

spots.name: San Francisco Museum and Historical Society
spots.body: The San Francisco Museum and Historical Society is a non profit organization dedicated to the preservation, interpretation, and presentation of the history of San Francisco and the surrounding Bay Area. The society conducts walking tours of San Francisco and holds monthly programs, tours, and other exhibitions.

spots.name: Fisherman's Wharf
spots.body: Fisherman's Wharf gets its name and neighborhood characteristics from the city's early days of the mid to later 1800s when Italian immigrant fishermen came to the city by the bay to take advantage of the influx of population due to the Gold Rush. Achille Paladini found success wholesaling local fish as owner of the Paladini Fish Company, and came to be known as the Fish King. Most of the Italian immigrant fishermen settled in the North Beach area close to the wharf and fished for the local delicacies and the now famed Dungeness crab.

spots.name: Union Square
spots.body: Union Square refers to the central shopping, hotel, and theater district that surrounds the plaza for several blocks. The area got its name because it was once used for rallies and support for the Union Army during the American Civil War.

spots.name: Chinatown
spots.body: The Chinatown is the oldest Chinatown in North America and the largest Chinese community outside Asia. Since its establishment in 1848, it has been highly important and influential in the history and culture of ethnic Chinese immigrants in North America.

spots.name: Ghirardelli Square
spots.body: Ghirardelli Square is a landmark public square with over 40 specialty shops and restaurants. Initially, in 1893, Domenico Ghirardelli purchased the entire city block in order to make it into the headquarters of the Ghirardelli Chocolate Company.

spots.name: Aquarium of the Bay
spots.body: Aquarium of the Bay is a public aquarium that is focused on local aquatic animals from the San Francisco Bay and neighboring waters. The Aquarium has over 50 sharks from species indigenous to the San Francisco Bay. It also has skates, bat rays and thousands of other animals including eels, flatfish, rockfish, Wrasse, Gobies, Kelpfish, Pricklebacks, Ronquil, Sculpin and Sturgeons.

spots.name: Ferry Building
spots.body: The Ferry Building is a terminal for ferries that travel across the San Francisco Bay and a food hall. It is a 245 foot tall clock tower which can be seen from Market Street, a main thoroughfare of the city. Designed in 1892 as Beaux Arts style, the ferry building was completed in 1898.

spots.name: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park
spots.body: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park includes a fleet of historic vessels, a visitor center, a maritime museum, and a research center. The historic fleet is moored at the park's Hyde Street Pier. The research center is the premier resource for San Francisco and Pacific Coast maritime history. Originating in 1939, the collections have become the largest maritime collection on the West Coast and the largest museum.

spots.name: San Francisco Zoo
spots.body: The San Francisco Zoo housed more than 1000 individual animals representing over 250 species as of 2016. It is the birthplace of Koko the gorilla known for having learned a large number of hand signs. The Black Rhinoceros said to be the oldest rhino in North America.

spots.name: Grace Cathedral
spots.body: Grace Cathedral is an Episcopal cathedral. The cathedral is famed for its mosaics by Jan Henryk De Rosen, a replica of Ghiberti's Gates of Paradise, varied stained glass windows, and medieval and contemporary furnishings, as well as its forty four bell carillon, three organs, and choirs. The cathedral's ancestral parish, Grace Church, was founded in 1849 during the California Gold Rush. The cathedral is the daughter of the historic Grace Church.

spots.name: Cliff House
spots.body: The Cliff House is a restaurant perched on the headland above the cliffs just north of Ocean Beach, on the western side of San Francisco. It has had several major incarnations since its beginnings in 1858. In 1896, Adolph Sutro built a new Cliff House, a seven story Victorian Chateau. The 1896 Cliff House survived the 1906 San Francisco earthquake with little damage, but burned to the ground on the evening of September 7, 1907. Dr. Emma Merritt, Sutro's daughter, commissioned a rebuilding of the restaurant in a neoclassical style that was completed within two years and is the basis of the structure seen today.

spots.name: Sutro Baths
spots.body: The Sutro Baths were a large, privately owned public saltwater swimming pool complex. In 1896, the Sutro Baths were opened to the public as the world's largest indoor swimming pool establishment. The facility burned down in June 1966 and is now in ruins.

spots.name: Presidio
spots.body: The Presidio of San Francisco is a park and former U.S. Army military fort. It had been a fortified location since September 17, 1776, when New Spain established it to gain a foothold. It passed to Mexico, which in turn passed it to the United States in 1848. On October 1, 1994, the military fort was transferred to the National Park Service, ending 219 years of military use.

spots.name: Haight Ashbury
spots.body: Haight Ashbury is a neighborhood known for its history of, and being the origin of hippie counterculture. The district is noted for its role as a center of the 1960s hippie movement. The earlier bohemians of the beat movement had congregated around San Francisco's North Beach neighborhood from the late 1950s. Many who could not find accommodation there turned to the quaint, relatively cheap and underpopulated Haight Ashbury. 1967 The Summer of Love, the 1960s era as a whole, and much of modern American counterculture have been synonymous with San Francisco and the Haight Ashbury neighborhood ever since.

spots.name: Mission District
spots.body: The Mission district is famous and influential for its restaurants. Dozens of taquerÃ­as are located throughout the neighborhood, showcasing a localized styling of Mexican food. Numerous Latino artistic and cultural institutions are based in the Mission District. Throughout the Mission walls and fences are decorated with murals initiated by the Chicano Art Mural Movement of the 1970s and inspired by the traditional Mexican paintings made famous by Diego Rivera.

spots.name: Tenderloin
spots.body: The Tenderloin is a neighborhood in downtown San Francisco. The Tenderloin took its name from an older neighborhood in New York with similar characteristics. Some said the name was a reference to the neighborhood as the soft underbelly, which is analogous to the cut of meat, with allusions to vice and corruption, especially graft. The Tenderloin is a high crime neighborhood, particularly violent street crime such as robbery and aggravated assault.

spots.name: Castro
spots.body: The Castro was one of the first gay neighborhoods in the United States. Having transformed from a working class neighborhood through the 1960s and 1970s, the Castro remains one of the most prominent symbols of LGBT activism and events in the world. 18th and Castro is a major intersection in the Castro, where many historic events, marches, protests have taken and continue to take place.

spots.name: Japantown
spots.body: San Francisco's Japantown is the largest and oldest such enclave in the United States. Built and settled in the 19th and early 20th century, Japanese immigrants began moving into the area following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. Before 1906, San Francisco had two Japantowns, one on the outskirts of Chinatown, the other in the South of Market area. By World War 2, the neighborhood was one of the largest such enclaves of Japanese outside Japan, as it took an appearance similar to the Ginza district in Tokyo.

spots.name: Treasure Island
spots.body: Treasure Island is an artificial island in San Francisco Bay. It was built for the 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition.

spots.name: Little Italy
spots.body: Little Italy is a neighborhood which has historically been home to a large Italian American population. It is still home to many Italian restaurants today. During the 1950s, many of the neighborhood's cafes and bars became the historic center of the beatnik subculture. The area also created innovations for the strip club industry including The Condor Club and The Lusty Lady.

spots.name: Powell Hyde Line & Powell Mason Line
spots.body: The Powell Hyde Line is a cable car line which starts at Powell & Market and ends at Hyde & Beach Streets, at Maritime Park. The Hyde Street Pier with historic sailing vessels and Ghirardelli Square are nearby. This line runs past the top of Lombard Street, before its final steep hill descent. The Powell Mason Line is a cable car line which starts at Powell & Market and ends at Taylor & Bay Streets, two blocks short of the middle section of Fishermen's Wharf. This is the oldest cable car line opened in 1888. This line directly intersects Little Italy, and stops along Mason Street two blocks west of Chinatown.

spots.name: Powell Hyde Line
spots.body: The Powell Hyde Line is a cable car line which starts at Powell & Market and ends at Hyde & Beach Streets, at Maritime Park. The Hyde Street Pier with historic sailing vessels and Ghirardelli Square are nearby. This line runs past the top of Lombard Street, before its final steep hill descent.

spots.name: Powell Mason Line
spots.body: The Powell Mason Line is a cable car line which starts at Powell & Market and ends at Taylor & Bay Streets, two blocks short of the middle section of Fishermen's Wharf. This is the oldest cable car line opened in 1888. This line directly intersects Little Italy, and stops along Mason Street two blocks west of Chinatown.

spots.name: California Street Line
spots.body: The California Street Line is a cable car line which starts at California Street & Drumm Street and ends at California Street & Van Ness Avenue. Unfortunately for tourists, the endpoint at California Street & Van Ness Avenue tends to be an anticlimactic destination. This line crosses through Chinatown.

spots.name: California Street Line
spots.body: The California Street Line is a cable car line which starts at California Street & Drumm Street and ends at California Street & Van Ness Avenue. Unfortunately for tourists, the endpoint at California Street & Van Ness Avenue tends to be an anticlimactic destination. This line crosses through Chinatown.

spots.name: Ocean Beach
spots.body: Ocean Beach is a beach on the west coast of San Francisco, bordering the Pacific Ocean. During the late spring and summer, San Francisco's characteristic foggy weather frequently envelops the beach. The beach is popular with surfers and participants in bonfire parties.

spots.name: Baker Beach
spots.body: Baker Beach lies on the shore of the Pacific Ocean in the northwest of the city. It is roughly a half mile long, beginning just south of Golden Gate Point where the Golden Gate Bridge connects with the peninsula. The northern section of Baker Beach is frequented by clothing optional sunbathers. As such it is considered a nude beach.

spots.name: Crissy Field
spots.body: Crissy Field, a former U.S. Army airfield, is now opened to the public. The western most part of Crissy Field includes a picnic area, and trails to the Golden Gate Bridge and Fort Point. The shoreline along Crissy Field has sand dunes which provide habitat for several native species.

spots.name: Lake Merced
spots.body: Lake Merced is a freshwater lake in the southwest corner of San Francisco. It was originally christened Laguna de Nuestra SeÃ±ora de la Merced by Captain Don Bruno de Heceta in 1775.

spots.name: AT&T Park
spots.body: AT&T Park is a baseball park located in the South Beach neighborhood of San Francisco. It has served as the home of the San Francisco Giants, the city's Major League Baseball franchise. AT&T Park has also played host to both professional and collegiate American football games.

spots.name: Kezar Stadium
spots.body: Kezar Stadium is an outdoor athletics stadium located adjacent to Kezar Pavilion in the southeastern corner of Golden Gate Park. It is the former home of the San Francisco Fourty Niners and the Oakland Raiders of the National Football League and of the San Francisco Dragons of Major League Lacrosse.

spots.name: Sausalito
spots.body: Sausalito is a seaside town across the Golden Gate bridge from San Francisco. Most of the frequently visited waterfront area can be seen on foot and are within easy walking distance from the ferry landing. The ferry services are offered from Pier 41 in Fisherman's Wharf and the historic Ferry Building. A very popular cycle for tourists to San Francisco is to hire a bike, cycle over the Golden Gate Bridge, and then down into Sausalito. There are full of great stores, restaurants, cafes and art studios in the town.

spots.name: Tiburon
spots.body: Tiburon is a small historic town located across the bay from San Francisco. The ferry services are offered from Pier 41 in Fisherman's Wharf and the Ferry Building. Tiburon's Main Street has been preserved as it was when the town was a Gold Rush train town and lumber yard.

spots.name: Golden Gate Park
spots.body: Golden Gate Park is a large urban park which is over three miles long east to west, and about half a mile north to south. There are gardens, playgrounds, lakes, picnic groves, trails, and monuments, plus an array of cultural venues, events, activities, and more than 13 million visitors annually, in the park. In the 1860s, SanFranciscans began to feel the need for a spacious public park similar to Central Park in New York City. From a vast, windswept expanse of sand dunes, the tireless field engineer William Hammond Hall prepared a survey and topographic map of the park site in 1870 and became its commissioner in 1871. The park drew its name from nearby Golden Gate Strait.

spots.name: Alamo Square
spots.body: Alamo Square is a residential neighborhood and park, with a number of large and architecturally distinctive mansions along the perimeter, including the Painted Ladies, a well known postcard motif. Named after the lone cottonwood tree, alamo in Spanish, Alamo Hill, was a watering hole on the horseback trail from Mission Dolores to the Presidio in the 1800s. In 1856, Mayor James Van Ness created a 12.7 acre park surrounding the watering hole, creating Alamo Square.

spots.name: Mission Dolores Park
spots.body: Mission Dolores Park offers several features including many tennis courts, a basketball court, a multi purpose court, a soccer field, a pissoir, a children's playground, and a dog play area. In recent years, the park's popularity among SanFranciscans looking for outdoor relaxation and recreation has increased, and as of 2016 it is attracting up to 7000 to 10000 people on a sunny weekend day. Native Americans of the Chutchui village of the Yelamu tribe inhabited the area prior to the arrival of Spanish missionaries, who founded nearby Mission Dolores in 1776. The park site formerly owned by Jewish congregations and was used as a Jewish cemetery, which became inactive in 1894. In 1905, the City of San Francisco bought the land. In 1906 and 1907, the park served as a refugee camp for more than 1600 families made homeless by the 1906 San Francisco earthquake and fire. Until after World War 2, the district was largely inhabited by European Americans, which from the 1950s to the 1970s were replaced by an influx of Latino immigrants.

spots.name: Lands End
spots.body: Lands End is a park which locates on northwestern corner of San Francisco. It is a rocky and windswept shoreline at the mouth of the Golden Gate strait, abutting Fort Miley Military Reservation. A memorial to the USS San Francisco stands in the park. Numerous hiking trails follow the former railbeds of the Ferries and Cliff House Railway along the cliffs and also down to the shore. Along the way, there are a stunning view, hillsides of cypress and wildflowers, views of old shipwrecks, access to the epic ruins of Sutro Baths, pocket beaches, and a new Lookout Visitor Center.

spots.name: Salud!
spots.body: Salud!, which means health in Spanish, are sixteen portraits of residents of the Bethany Senior Center adorn the wall of the building. They were painted in 1997 by Dan Fontes.

spots.name: Women's Building Mural
spots.body: Women's Building Mural was painted in 1994 by seven artists. The Women's Building is a women led non profit arts and education community center, which advocates self determination, gender equality and social justice. The mural features images of feminine icons from history and fiction, and the names of more than 600 women written in calligraphy.

spots.name: No One Is Illegal
spots.body: No One Is Illegal is a mural painted by Laura Campos. She was born in Mexico and often called an illegal alien, which is why she often paints aliens in her work.

spots.name: Carnaval
spots.body: Carnaval is an iconic realist mural from Daniel Galvez. It references the very first Mission's annual Carnaval celebration in 1979.

spots.name: Generator
spots.body: Generator is a twisted dreamscape of interlocking birdhouses and morphed elements. The striking mural quietly references the Ellis Act, which is a California state law that allows landlords to evict residential tenants. It shows birds fleeing from their homes.

spots.name: Evolutionary Rainbow
spots.body: Evolutionary Rainbow is a mural Yana Zegri first painted way back in 1967. It was never formally titled, but was called Evolution Rainbow because as the colors of its rainbow design progressed from dark to light, details within each color depicted the evolution of animals from early protozoa through dinosaurs up to modern species.

spots.name: Professor Wangari Maathai
spots.body: Professor Wangari Maathai is a mural paying tribute to Kenyan Greenbelt movement leader Wangari Maathai. Greenbelt is non profit organization, which takes a holistic approach to development by focusing on environmental conservation, community development and capacity building. Kate Decicco and Delvin Kenobe painted Maathai following her death in 2011

spots.name: Self-Destruction
spots.body: Self Destruction is a mural painted by twin brothers and Brooklyn based street artists How and Nosm. They have said that the street art saved the neighborhood from drugs. The mural is painted in their distinctive black, red, and white palette.

spots.name: Fear Head
spots.body: Fear Head is fed by the neighborhood's homeless residents, drug dealers, immigrants, police, tourists, and prostitutes every time they encounter fear. The mural was painted in 2009 as part of a public art exhibit called Wonderland.

spots.name: Battery Ledyard
spots.body: Battery Ledyard was a reinforced concrete, 5 inch rapid fire coastal gun battery. Battery construction started and was completed in 1900. The battery was named in 1902. Deactivated in 1915 when the guns and carriages were removed.

spots.name: Nike Missile Control Site SF-91
spots.body: Nike Missile Control Site SF 91 was opened in 1955. The IFC, which is a radar, was located at the top of Mount Livermore, the highest point on Angel Island. This site was closed in 1961. All that is left of the IFC is one building, some concrete radar pads, a redwood water tank and some cables sticking out of the ground.

spots.name: Camp Reynolds
spots.body: Camp Reynolds was established, with concern mounting over threats from Confederate naval raiders, in 1863. After the Civil War, Camp Reynolds became an infantry camp, serving as a depot for recruits, and as a staging area for troops serving in campaigns against Indian tribes.

spots.name: Angel Island
spots.body: Angel Island is an island in San Francisco Bay. It has been used for a variety of purposes, including military forts, a US Public Health Service Quarantine Station, and a US Bureau of Immigration inspection and detention facility. In 1775, the Spanish naval vessel San Carlos made the first European entry to the San Francisco Bay under the command of Juan de Ayala. Ayala anchored off Angel Island, and gave it its modern name, Isla de los Ãngeles. The bay where he anchored is now known as Ayala Cove. Angel Island was subsequently used for cattle ranching. In 1863, during the American Civil War, the U.S. Army was concerned about Confederate naval raiders attacking San Francisco. It decided to construct artillery batteries on Angel Island.

spots.name: Japanese Tea Garden
spots.body: The Japanese Tea Garden was originally built as part of a sprawling World's Fair, the California Midwinter International Exposition of 1894. The oldest public Japanese garden in the United States, this complex of many paths, ponds and a teahouse features plants and trees pruned and arranged in a Japanese style. The garden contains sculptures and structures influenced by Buddhist and Shinto religious beliefs, as well as many elements of water and rocks to create a calming landscape designed to slow people down.

spots.name: Conservatory of Flowers
spots.body: The Conservatory of Flowers is a greenhouse and botanical garden that houses a collection of rare and exotic plants. The conservatory contains approximately 1700 plant species. With construction having been completed in 1879, it is the oldest remaining municipal wooden conservatory in the US. The building is an elaborate Victorian greenhouse with a central dome rising nearly 60 feet high and arch shaped wings extending from it for an overall length of 240 feet.

spots.name: Beach Chalet
spots.body: The two story Beach Chalet was opened in 1925 in Spanish colonial revival style as a city run restaurant and included changing rooms for beach visitors. Elaborate murals were added to the first floor in 1936.

spots.name: Fort Cronkhite
spots.body: Fort Cronkhite is a former US Army post that served as part of the coastal artillery defenses of the San Francisco Bay Area during World War 2. The soldiers at Cronkhite manned gun batteries, radar sites, and other fortifications on the high ridges overlooking the fort.

spots.name: Golden Gate Park Windmills
spots.body: There are two functioning windmills on the western edge of Golden Gate Park. The northern Dutch Windmill was completed in 1903, and the southern Murphy Windmill was completed in 1908. In the 1870s and 1880s, Golden Gate Park was planted on sand dunes and required substantial irrigation. In 1902, the Park Commission authorized the construction of two windmills to pump groundwater for park irrigation rather than purchasing water at exorbitant costs from the Spring Valley Water Company.

spots.name: San Francisco Botanical Garden
spots.body: The San Francisco Botanical Garden includes over 50000 individual plants, representing over 8000 taxa from around the world, with particular focus on Magnolia species, high elevation palms, and cloud forest species from Central America, South America and Southeast Asia. Due to the unique climate of San Francisco, the plants range from a variety of different national origins, some of them no longer existing in their natural habitats. These regions of origin go from desert to tropical. In addition, some native California species are housed in the garden as well, such as Redwood trees.

spots.name: Bison Paddock
spots.body: Bison Paddock was created in 1899. Bisons have been kept in Golden Gate Park since 1891. At the time, the animal's population in North America had dwindled to an all time low, and San Francisco made a successful effort to breed them in captivity.

spots.name: Battery Spencer
spots.body: Battery Spencer was a reinforced concrete gun battery. Battery construction was begun in 1893, completed in 1897, and transferred to the Coast Artillery for use 1897. It was deactivated in 1942 during World War 2.

spots.name: Moscone Center
spots.body: Moscone Center is the largest convention and exhibition complex in San Francisco. It is known for hosting several large professional gatherings, such as the Apple Worldwide Developers Conference, Google I/O, Oracle OpenWorld, and Game Developers Conference.

spots.name: Old Saint Mary's Cathedral
spots.body: Old Saint Mary's Cathedral is a cathedral and parish of the Roman Catholic Church. In 1854, it became the first cathedral in California. When it opened, it was the tallest building in California. Under the clock face of Old Saint Mary's appear the words. Son, Observe the Time and Fly from Evil. This sentiment was aimed at the men who frequented the surrounding brothels in the 1850s.

spots.name: Waverly Place
spots.body: Waverly Place, a street with many temples, is aptly called The Street of Painted Balconies for its colorful and decorative buildings. The oldest Buddhist temple in the United States, Tien Hou, was built in 1852.

spots.name: Portsmouth Square
spots.body: Portsmouth Square is considered a part of Chinatown today. However, it was originally established as a site of the first public square in the early 19th century in the Mexican community of Yerba Buena, whose name was changed to San Francisco in 1847. During the Mexican American War, in 1846, the first American flag was raised near the Mexican adobe custom house in the plaza that would eventually be named Portsmouth Square in honor of the ship. Many historical events have happened at the plaza. For example, in 1848, the discovery of gold was announced.

spots.name: Castro Theatre
spots.body: Castro Theatre is a popular San Francisco movie palace. It was built in 1922 with a Spanish Colonial Baroque faÃ§ade. Today, the theatre hosts repertory movies, film festivals, and special events, including gay and multicultural focus.

spots.name: Washington Square
spots.body: Washington Square is a park established in 1847. It is bordered by sidewalk cafes and restaurants such as Mama's and the Liguria Bakery as well as Saints Peter and Paul Church which is cultural center for San Francisco's Italian American community.

spots.name: City Lights Bookstore
spots.body: City Lights Bookstore is an independent bookstore publisher combination that specializes in world literature, the arts, and progressive politics. It also houses the nonprofit City Lights Foundation, which publishes selected titles related to San Francisco culture. It was founded in 1953 by poets.

spots.name: Beat Museum
spots.body: Beat Museum is dedicated to spreading the spirit of The Beat Generation, which we define as tolerance, compassion and having the courage to live your individual truth. The Beats were a collective of writers, artists and thinkers that congregated in 1950s San Francisco. The museum is home to an extensive collection of Beat memorabilia, including original manuscripts and first editions, letters, personal effects and cultural ephemera.

spots.name: Bimbo's 365
spots.body: Bimbo's 365 is an entertainment club that specializes in live rock and jazz shows. The building started as Bal Tabarin in 1931, the same year that the 365 Club started at 365 Market Street. The two locations under separate ownership consolidated in 1951 to one location owned by Agostino Bimbo Giuntoli, who was an Italian immigrant. His boss was unable to pronounce his name and dubbed him Bimbo, the Italian word for boy.

spots.name: Condor Club
spots.body: Condor Club is a striptease bar or topless bar. The club opened in 1964. The large lit sign in front of the club featured a picture of Carol Doda, who was the first topless entertainer. The club closed in 2000, but soon reopened as a sports bar bistro. In 2007, it once again became the Condor and started featuring go go dancers.
